Ventilation Issues

--- Page 118 ---
VENTILATOR ASSOCIATED PNEUMONIA
PATHOPHYSIOLOGY

DEFINITION
pneumonia in patient mechanically
ventilated 48 h

RISK FACTORS
prolonged mechanical ventilation,
need for reintubation, aspiration of gastric con
tents, acid suppression therapy, supine position
ing, poor oral/dental hygiene

MICROBIOLOGY
predominantly S. aureus (includ
ing MRSA), Enterobacteriaceae, Pseudomonas aer
uginosa. Other common microorganisms include
Stenotrophomonas, Acinetobacter, anaerobes
DIAGNOSIS
diagnosis can be difficult. Clinical
scores can be used to aid in diagnosis
TREATMENTS

EMPIRIC THERAPY
anti pseudomonal carbapenem or
b lactam/b lactamase inhibitor plus aminoglycoside
or respiratory fluoroquinolone. Add vancomycin or
linezolid if high rates of MRSA. De escalate therapy
as soon as possible when culture results known

DURATION OF THERAPY
depends on the microor
ganism, severity of infection, patient comorbidities
and response to therapy, but short courses gener
ally adequate (7 8 days)

APPROACH
‘‘while no single sign is diagnostic of
VAP, the appearance of a new infiltrate on CXR
should prompt one to check for fever, purulent
sputum and leukocytosis (VAP becomes more likely
when 2 or more of these signs are positive). Analy
sis of pulmonary secretions can further refine the
diagnosis of VAP. The absence of CXR infiltrate
moderately decreases the chance of VAP’’
